Metadata: Cattail invasion and persistence in a coastal salt marsh: the role of salinity reduction

The hypothesis that "Typha domingensis" (cattail) can invade tidal marshes only after soil salinities are substantially reduced was tested experimentally. Germination rates for four southern California populations reached 100% in fresh water, decreasing to 2% at 20 ppt salinity. Rhizome-bearing plants had greatly decreased growth at 10 ppt and no growth at 25 ppt; however, rhizomes of about 5% of the plants survived 9 months at 45 ppt. The seeds and seedlings are salt sensitive, which explains why invasion into tidal marshes is restricted to prolonged periods of low soil salinity. The older, rhizome-bearing plants are salt tolerant, and can persist under hypersaline conditions.
